chapter.title: API Reference

section.title: Credential Management
section.para: Most Active Directory operations require authentication. The default authentication mechanism in AD is Kerberos. Unfortunately, it has always been difficult to use Kerberos authentication with AD. It required for example to have a properly configured /etc/krb5.conf listing the realms you want to use and the Kerbers servers for those realms.

Fortunately Python-AD simplifies AD credential management significantly. It does not require any system configuration and all functionality is embedded in a single class named Creds. This class is available from the Python package ad
section.programlisting: from ad import Creds
section.para: The constructor for the Creds class takes one argument: domain. This parameter specifies the default AD domain for credential management.
The domain parameter is used as a default when principals are used without domain name. Credentials in any other domains can be acquired as long as the domain is part of the same AD forest.
The Creds class has the following methods:
section.programlisting: def acquire(self, principal, password=None, keytab=None, server=None): """Acquire credentials."""
section.para: The acquire() function acquires credentials for principal principal. The principal can either a unqualified principal, in which case the default domain is assumed, or a principal in the form of user@domain in which case domain must be a domain in the same AD forest as the default domain. The password contains the password to the principal. If no password is given, a keytab will be used. This keytab is can be specified by the keytab parameter. If this parameter is not present either, the default system keytab is used. The server argument overrides the default Kerberos server to acquire credentials from. If this argument is not given, a suitable Kerberos server is autodetected.
section.programlisting: def load(self): """Load credentials from the OS."""
section.para: The function load() loads credentials from the default operating system credentials store. It raises an exception in case no credentials are available.
section.programlisting: def principal(self): """Return the current principal."""
section.para: The principal() method returns the current principal, i.e. the principal that was last succesfully used in a call to acquire().
section.programlisting: def release(self): """Release all credentials."""
section.para: The release() method releases the currently held credentials. It is called automatically from the Creds destructor.

Once credentials are acquired with acquire(), they need to be activated before they can be used. This is required because credentials are a process-global resource and they need to be installed in a place where other classes in Python-AD will be able to find them. Credential activation is done by calling a function called activate() as follows:
section.programlisting: from ad import activate activate(creds)
section.para: The code fragment above will make the creds object the globally active credentials. The activate() can be called multiple times on different objects. The semantics are that the object on which activate() was called last will be the active credentials. If active credentials are released by calling the release() method of a Creds instance, then the credentials that were previously active are activated. If no previously activated credentials exist, there will be no credentials available after this call.

section.title: AD Client Interface
section.para: The actual operations on Active Directory are grouped in a single class called Client. This class is available from the ad package.
section.programlisting: from ad import Client
section.para: The constructor to the Client class takes one argument: the domain.

The domain parameter sets the default domain for the Client class. As with the Creds class, the requirement to specify the domain does not mean that operations through the client are limited to the specified domain: all operations are available to any domain that is part of the same forest.
Instances of the Client class will try to access the globally installed Creds instance. Therefore you must ensure that credentials are available before you use any functionality in this class.
The following methods are provided by the Client class:
section.programlisting: def domain_name_from_dn(self, dn): """Given a DN, return a domain."""
section.para: The function domain_name_from_dn() is a utility function that, given an LDAP distinguished name, will return the Active Directory domain name. For example, if the dn parameter is set to cn=users,dc=freeadi,dc=org, the return value of this method will be FREEADI.ORG.
section.programlisting: def dn_from_domain_name(self, name): """Given a domain name, return a DN."""
section.para: The function dn_from_domain_name() is the inverse of domain_name_from_dn(). For example, if name is set to LINUX.FREEADI.ORG, the return value of this method will be dc=linux,dc=freeadi,dc=org.
section.programlisting: def domain(self): """Return the domain name of the current domain."""
section.para: This method returns the current default domain.
section.programlisting: def domain_base(self): """Return the base DN of the domain."""
section.para: The method domain_base() returns the LDAP base DN for the curent domain. If client is an instance of Client, then this is equivalent to client.dn_from_domain_name(client.domain()).
section.programlisting: def forest(self): """Return the domain name of the forest root."""
section.para: This method returns the root of the forest for the current domain. In case the current domain is a child domain, this will return something different than the domain() method.
section.programlisting: def forest_base(self): """Return the base DN of the forest root."""
section.para: The forest_base() method returns the LDAP base DN for the forest. This function is equivalent to client.dn_from_domain_name(client.forest()).
section.programlisting: def schema_base(self): """Return the base DN of the schema naming_context."""
section.para: This method returns the LDAP base DN for the schema naming context for the Active Directory forest.
section.programlisting: def configuration_base(self): """Return the base DN of the configuration naming_context."""
section.para: This method returns the LDAP base DN for the configuration namign context for the Active Directory forest.
section.programlisting: def naming_contexts(self): """Return a list of all naming_contexts."""
section.para: The naming_contexts() returns a list of all naming contexts in the forest. The term naming context is the Microsoft name for a directory partition. Each naming context is present on one or multiple domain controllers, and each domain controller normally has multiple naming contexts.
section.programlisting: def domains(self): """Return a list of all domains in the forest."""
section.para: This function returns a list of all domains that are present in the forest.
section.programlisting: def close(self): """Close any active LDAP connection."""
section.para: The close() closes all currently open connections to the Active Directory.

The search() method is probably the most important function in Python-AD. It searches the Active Directory and returns a list of objects that match the query. The filter argument specifies the LDAP search filter. If it is absent, the default filter is (objectClass=*). The base arguments gives the LDAP search base. This search base must either be blank ('') in which case the rootDSE is searched, or it must be within one of the naming contexts of the forest. The scope parameter must be a string of the value 'base', 'onelevel' or 'subtree'. For compatibility reasons, the SCOPE_* constants as defined by Python-LDAP are accepted as well. The attrs parameter specifies the attributes to request. If it is given, it must be a list of strings. If it is not specified, then the default is to request all attributes. The server parameter is another optional parameter that specifies the server to bind to. Normally, Python-AD operates in serverless binding mode. In this mode, a suitable domain controller is selected automatically. In some situation this may not be desidered however and for these situations the server can be used. Finally the scheme parameter specifies the search scheme. It must be one of 'ldap' (the default) or 'gc' to search the global catalog.

The return value of search() is a list of 2-tuples. Each tuple consists of a distinguished name and a dictionary of attributes. The dictionary has string keys (the attribute names) and a list of strings as it values (the attribute values).
section.programlisting: def add(self, dn, attrs, server=None): """Add a new object to Active Directory."""
section.para: The add() function adds an object to the directory. The parameter dn specifies the distinguished name of the attribute to be added. The parameter attrs specifies the attributes of the object. It must be a list of 2-tuples, with the first tuple entry the attribute name, and the second tuple entry a list of strings containing the attribute values. The server parameter can be used to override the default binding behaviour and has the same meaning as for search().
section.programlisting: def modify(self, dn, mods, server=None): """Modify an LDAP object."""
section.para: The modify() method modifies an existing object in the directory. The dn parameter specifies the distinguished name of the object modify, while mods specifies the modifications. The latter must be a list of 3-tuples. Each tuple consists of the modify operation (one of 'add', 'replace' or 'delete' to add, replace or delete an attribute value respectively -- the Python-LDAP MOD_* constants are supported for compatibility), the attribute name, and the attribute value. The latter must be a list of strings. The server parameter can be used to override the default binding behaviour and has the same meaning as for search().
section.programlisting: def delete(self, dn, server=None): """Delete the LDAP object referenced by `dn'."""
section.para: The delete() method removes an object from the directory. The dn parameter specifies the distinguished name of the object to remove. The server parameter can be used to override the default binding behaviour and has the same meaning as for search().
section.programlisting: def modrdn(self, dn, newrdn, delold=True, server=None): """Change the RDN of an object in Active Direcotry."""
section.para: The modrdn() method modifies the relative distinuished name of the LDAP object with distinguished name dn to the value specified by the newrdn, which must be in the form of "attr=value". The delold specifies whether the old RDN value is retained or not. The server parameter has the same meaning as for search().
The rename() method is like modrdn() but is also allows the object to be moved to a new place in the directory by means of the newsuperior parameter.
section.programlisting: def set_password(self, principal, password, server=None): """Set the password of `principal' to `password'."""
section.para: This function sets the password for principal to password. The server parameter can again be used to override the default server binding as for the search() method.
section.programlisting: def change_password(self, principal, oldpass, newpass, server=None): """Change the password of `principal' to `password'."""
section.para: This function changes the password for principal principal. The old password must be given in oldpass and the new password in newpass.

chapter.section:
Resource Location
Resource location is an problem that is normally handled transparently by Python-AD. In the default situation, domain controllers are looked up automatically by a global instance of the Locator class. It is possible however to use this class directly. This is most useful when targetting a specific domain controller with the server argument that many methods of the Client class accept.
The Locator class is available from the ad package:
from ad import Locator
The constructor takes one optional parameter: the site.
class Locator(object): """Locate domain controllers.
def __init__(self, site=None): """Constructor."""
The site specifies the AD site the current system is in. Normally this value is autodetected, but in some situations you may want to override this.
The Locator class defines the following methods:
def locate(self, domain, role=None): """Locate one domain controller."""
The locate() method locates one domain controller for the domain domain. The optional parameter role, if given, specifies the desired role of the domain controller. This can be one of 'dc', 'gc' or 'pdc' for a normal domain controller, a global catalog, or the domain controller with the primary domain controller emulator role respectively. The default is to locate an ordinary domain controller. The return value of this method is a string containing the host name of the domain controller. If no domain controller is found, an exception is raised.
def locate_many(self, domain, role=None, maxservers=None): """Locate a list of up to `maxservers' of domain controllers."""
This method locates up to maxservers domain controllers. The domain and role parameters are as for locate(). The return value is a list of strings containing the host names of the selected domain controllers. If no domain controllers are found, an empty list is returned.

Error Handling
Two exceptions are defined for error handling. It is recommended to import the exception as per the code fragment below:
from ad import Error as ADError from ad import LDAPError
The ADError exception is raised for all errors that are encountered by Python-AD. The LDAPError exception is imported from Python-LDAP and is raised when an exception is raised by that module. Therefore, to ensure that all exceptions are caught, you always need to capture both exceptions, as illustrated by the example below:
client = Client(domain) try: client.add(dn, attrs) except (ADError, LDAPError): pass
